title: Three sisters and three ukuleles
creator_contributor_role: Australia. Dept. of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations, partner
viewing_guidelines: Aboriginal and Islander viewers should note this work may contain images of deceased people and caution should be exercised when viewing.
subject_group: Anthropology, Ethnology, Exploration & Travel/Torres Strait Islands (Qld.)
Anthropology, Ethnology, Exploration & Travel/Torres Strait Islanders
Armed Forces, Military, War & Weapons/World War, 1939-1945 - Australia
Armed Forces, Military, War & Weapons/World War, 1939-1945 - Pacific Area
abstract: Gran and her sisters didn't do it for the fame or the money, they did it because it was what they loved.
description: T'Kido Titasey dedicates this story to his grandmother. Born a Torres Strait Islander, she never received a formal education but was taught about survival. After World War II, she set up a ukulele band with her two sisters. It became popular and The Mill Sisters travelled around the world and landed a recording deal. Gran's resourcefulness and eagerness to try new things took her and her sisters on an amazing adventure and has been an immense inspiration to T'Kido.
part_of_compliation_title_or_vod_package: Compilation title; B2001903; This is me : foundation for young Australians (July 2009) : Digital Storytelling project; Active; 2009
